JAYS RESUME PLAY
WITH MT. WASHINGTON
Will Renew Relations Broken
Five Years Ago
.
LAST GAME SCHEDULED
Finest Brand of Lacrosse Is
Expected to Be Displayed
The Johns Hopkins and Mt.
Washington lacrosse twelves have
renewed relations and will meet- at
Homewood on June 8, for the first
time in five years. The decision to
continue the annual lacrosse classic
wals made public last week by Harry
0. Norris, president of the Mt.
Washington Club and for many
years an ,ardent follower, booster
and player of the Indian game.
.

Outstanding Game

Price 5 Cents

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 19, 1929

DONOR OF LIBRARY
PLATES REVEALED
The N ws-LETTER yesterday received the following letter from Dr. French in reference to the name-plates which
have recently been placed under the faculty portraits in the
Main Reading Room. The letter follow:
To the Editor of the
NEWS-LETTER.
Sir:
One of your'correspondents.
has been kind enough to express in the NEWS-LETTER appreciation of the name-plates
recently placed on the portraits
in the main reading room. It
is but fair to make known the
fact that this long-needeed improvement is due to the generosity of a Baltimore artist,
Mr. G. E. Code, who made
the markeri, __and - presented
them to the Library.
-Phi
Librarian.

JUNIOR CLASStNAMES
DANCE COMMITTEE
At a meeting of the Junior
Class held last Friday, nominations were received for Junior delegate to the Student
Council.
Vice-President Smith presided in the absence of President Hall. Scheidt and Linthicum were the men nominated for the position:
The committee in charge of
the Junior Dance appointed by
Hill was announced to be
Smith, chairman; Swope, Lin,
thicum, Parker, and Norris.
No date has been set for the
dance, but in the near future
the committee will meet to set
a date.
Nominations will be reopened at the next meeting,
_
which will be held.
At,the Friday meeting only
15 men were present, but it is
necessary to have a much larger turnout if the election is to
be held. All Juniors are urged
to attend the next meeting,
which will be held on Thursday, after assembly.

ACTIVITIES COUNCIL
AWARDS VARSITY SEALS

MUSICAL CLUB GIVES
ZION CHURCH CONCERT

HOPKINS SWIMMERS
DOWN W.L. TEAM
Capture Close Meet in Final
Event
SCORE IS 32 TO 30
Freshmen Lose Water Polo to
City College
A small but enthusiastic.,crowd
witnessed the I lopkins mermen
swim to their first victory o,f the
season Saturday night, when they
defeated Washington and Lee's
team by a score of 32 to 30.
This defeat is the first that the
Generals have met this season, since
they were the victors in their first
four meets before coming to Baltimore.
Last Event Clinches Meet
It was the last event of the meet
which gave Hopkins the victory.
Coming to this event with the score
29 to 24 against them, the Jay men
determined to take first and second
places in the 100-yard dash and so
capture the meet. Welsh and Stewart were the two Hopkins entries in
this event and they swam the two
and a half lengths so closely together that the judges could not decide who took first and who took
second places. Stewart was finally
awarded the first honors, Welsh,
second, and Moffatt, of Washington and Lee, took third place.
Summary

The meet began on, scheduled
time with the 160-yard relay, which
the Black and Blue swimmers took
by two-fifths of a second. It was
a beautiful race and close throughout, each of the four swimmers cutting through the water at his best
speed:
200-yard breast-stroke was won
by Washington and Lee; second
place was also taken by one of the
visitors. Dorman was so close to
these two men that it was not until
the last few strokes that the W. &
L. men captured the first and second counts.
In the 40-yard dash, Captain Hiss
and Welsh swam neck to neck to
take the first two places, respectively. Ayars, of Washington and Lee,
was close in third place, giving the
race enough competition to keep the
spectators on their ,feet the whole
race.
The diving, in which the visitors
took first and second prizes, was
the next event of the evening..This
was featured by the very pretty diving of t.mith, of W.& L., who took
first place b3,an easy margin. Martin, of the Southern team, jut nosed
out Meyers, of J. H. U., by'a score
of 65.2 to 64.2 for second place.
First place in the 150-yard back
stroke went to Moffatt of the Generals' team, Captain Hiss took second, and Cook, a visitor, took third.
Hopkins' second back-stroker, Hoffman, was out of the meet, due to an
injury received while practicing in
the pool earlier in the day. The
time for the event, 2 minutes 1 3-5
seconds, bettered the Hopkins
record, set by Hiss in 1927, by three
seconds.
Campbell took sectnd place in the
440-yard swim for the Hopkins
team, first and third places going
to the visitors. The time made by
Smith, W.& L., of 6 minutes 16 3-5
seconds, beat the Hopkins record by
17 3-5 seconds. Valliant, the Jay's

109 SENIORS HAVE

PAID CLASS DUES
One hundred and nine men
have paid their senior class
dues, according to M. H. Medenbach, treasurer of the senior
class. Last Friday was the
last day on which dues could
be paid, said Medenbach, and
those who have not paid will
be eliminated from the group
to appear in the Hullabalo. A
very small percentage of the
class is included in those whO
have not paid. The amount of
the dues was twenty-nine dollars per senior; and was payable until February.

While we are in this particularly
gay and festive post-examination
period of the academic year, as the
residents o4 the Alumni Memorial
Hall stretch physical feet toward
the radiators and mental feet toward the warmth of the early Maryland spring, your correspondent is
moved to offer a constructive suggestion.
It has to do with the Alumni
Memorial- Hall. and it is in short a
plan to make the hall more truly
memorial of certain great alumni.
The ekpense involved is so Ismail as
to be negligible, and a simple resolution of the Bdard of Governors
or whatever it is will suffice in a
parliamentary way.
Your correspondent therefore not
too respectfully suggests that the
several entries, which are now designated by the opening letters of
our Roman alphabet, should henceforth and forever be designed by
the names of distinguished alumni.
• • •
Your correspondent suggests that
each of the several important departments of this university be
given an entry to name for its favorite. By important, your correspondent means the chemical, the
physical, the biological, the medical,
and the new legal departments.
The sixth entry has already been
taken over by the alumni, who have
had it named after the late Judge
S.- S. Symington. The engineering
department is not, it is submitted,
entitled to an entry.

Pipe Smoker
Has a "Kick"
All His Own
St. Paul, Minn.
June 1, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
About five years ago, after trying
out many different styles of pipes
from the Missouri meerschaum to the
genuine meerschaum, including the
upside-down style made popular by
Vice-President Dawes, and experimenting with just about all the to-.
baccos then on the market except
Edgeworth,I finally decided that pipesmoking was not for me.
For the last year or so I noticed the
boys around the office here using
Edgeworth to the exclusion of all
other tobaccos and evidently getting
real pleasure from their pipes.
In April of this year I was in Canada
on a business trip and decided to take
another whirl at pipe-smoking. So I
invested a good share of my savings
in a pipe and a few cents additional
for a can of Edgeworth.
From then on I have been figuratively kicking myself around the block
about once each day when I think of
the five lean years I put in trying to
get along without a pipe. However, I
am trying to make up for lost time
and am succeeding quite well. Why
I failed to try Edgeworth long ago will
have to go down in history as an
unsolved question. But now that I
have found it, the years ahead look
rosy to me.
Very truly yours,
Ben Bayer

Underwriters' Agent Gives
Engineering Lecture

Speaking on a subject little known
but vastly important to the average person, Mr. George B. Aluldaur,
General Agent of the Underwriters'
Laboratories of Chicago and New
York, described the testing of various machines and other commercial
aPpliances presented to his organization for inspection. The lecture
was held last Wednesday and was
the second of a series of three lectures that are being held this spring
on engineering practice.
'The Underwriters' Laboratories
is a non-profit-making organization
sponsored by various Insurance organizations throughout the country,
for the purpose of standardizing and
testing the quality of all types and
classes of commercial products. The
general offices are at 'Chicago in a
large _building occupying a full block
and protected by every knoWn fire
and burglar safety device known.
Several hundred men are employed
merely in testing the commercial
products submitted. A small laboratory in New York City takes
charge of the examination of all
electrical devices.
Slides Most Interesting

Of most interest were the illustrations and slides—presented along
with the descriptions by Mr. Muldaur, showing the terrific tests put
on such objects as safes. In determining whether the Laboratories
will put,this approval on a certain
safe it is put in a very hot furnace
and baked for several hotirs; It is
removed, raised to a height of thirty
feet, and permitted to fall to a bed
of rock. It is then put in the furnace and reheated for a time. Then
it is removed and opened. If the
papers originally put in the safe are
burned or even charred the safe is
rejected.

Finest Brand of Lacrosse Is
Expected to Be Displayed
The Johns Hopkins and Mt.
Washington lacrosse twelves have
renewed relations and will meet- at
Homewood on June 8, for the first
time in five years. The decision to
continue the annual lacrosse classic
wals made public last week by Harry
0. Norris, president of the Mt.
Washington Club and for many
years an ,ardent follower, booster
and player of the Indian game.

PLATES REVEALED
The N ws-LETTER yesterday received the following letter from Dr. French in reference to the name-plates which
have recently been placed under the faculty portraits in the
Main Reading Room. The letter follow:
To the Editor of the
NEWS-LETTER.

One of your'correspondents.
has been kind enough to express in the NEWS-LETTER appreciation of the name-plates
recently placed on the portraits
in the main reading room. It
is but fair to make known the
fact that this long-needeed improvement is due to the generosity of a Baltimore artist,
Mr. G. E. Code, who made
the markeri, __and - presented
them to the Library.

At a meeting of the Junior
Class held last Friday, nominations were received for Junior delegate to the Student
Council.
Vice-President Smith presided in the absence of President Hall. Scheidt and Linthicum were the men nominated for the position:
The committee in charge of
the Junior Dance appointed by
Hill was announced to be
Smith, chairman; Swope, Lin,
thicum, Parker, and Norris.
No date has been set for the
dance, but in the near future
the committee will meet to set
a date.
Nominations will be reopened at the next meeting,
_
which will be held.
At,the Friday meeting only
15 men were present, but it is
necessary to have a much larger turnout if the election is to
be held. All Juniors are urged
to attend the next meeting,
which will be held on Thursday, after assembly.

HOPKINS SWIMMERS
DOWN W.L. TEAM
Capture Close Meet in Final
Event
SCORE IS 32 TO 30
Freshmen Lose Water Polo to
City College
A small but enthusiastic.,crowd
witnessed the I lopkins mermen
swim to their first victory o,f the
season Saturday night, when they
defeated Washington and Lee's
team by a score of 32 to 30.
This defeat is the first that the
Generals have met this season, since
they were the victors in their first
four meets before coming to Baltimore.
Last Event Clinches Meet
It was the last event of the meet
which gave Hopkins the victory.
Coming to this event with the score
29 to 24 against them, the Jay men
determined to take first and second
places in the 100-yard dash and so
capture the meet. Welsh and Stewart were the two Hopkins entries in
this event and they swam the two
and a half lengths so closely together that the judges could not decide who took first and who took
second places. Stewart was finally
awarded the first honors, Welsh,
second, and Moffatt, of Washington and Lee, took third place.
Summary

The meet began on, scheduled
time with the 160-yard relay, which
the Black and Blue swimmers took
by two-fifths of a second. It was
a beautiful race and close throughout, each of the four swimmers cutting through the water at his best
speed:
200-yard breast-stroke was won
by Washington and Lee; second
place was also taken by one of the
visitors. Dorman was so close to
these two men that it was not until
the last few strokes that the W. &
L. men captured the first and second counts.
In the 40-yard dash, Captain Hiss
and Welsh swam neck to neck to
take the first two places, respectively. Ayars, of Washington and Lee,
was close in third place, giving the
race enough competition to keep the
spectators on their ,feet the whole
race.
The diving, in which the visitors
took first and second prizes, was
the next event of the evening..This
was featured by the very pretty diving of t.mith, of W.& L., who took
first place b3,an easy margin. Martin, of the Southern team, jut nosed
out Meyers, of J. H. U., by'a score
of 65.2 to 64.2 for second place.
First place in the 150-yard back
stroke went to Moffatt of the Generals' team, Captain Hiss took second, and Cook, a visitor, took third.
Hopkins' second back-stroker, Hoffman, was out of the meet, due to an
injury received while practicing in
the pool earlier in the day. The
time for the event, 2 minutes 1 3-5
seconds, bettered the Hopkins
record, set by Hiss in 1927, by three
seconds.
Campbell took sectnd place in the
440-yard swim for the Hopkins
team, first and third places going
to the visitors. The time made by
Smith, W.& L., of 6 minutes 16 3-5
seconds, beat the Hopkins record by
17 3-5 seconds. Valliant, the Jay's

109 SENIORS HAVE

PAID CLASS DUES
One hundred and nine men
have paid their senior class
dues, according to M. H. Medenbach, treasurer of the senior
class. Last Friday was the
last day on which dues could
be paid, said Medenbach, and
those who have not paid will
be eliminated from the group
to appear in the Hullabalo. A
very small percentage of the
class is included in those whO
have not paid. The amount of
the dues was twenty-nine dollars per senior; and was payable until February.

While we are in this particularly
gay and festive post-examination
period of the academic year, as the
residents o4 the Alumni Memorial
Hall stretch physical feet toward
the radiators and mental feet toward the warmth of the early Maryland spring, your correspondent is
moved to offer a constructive suggestion.
It has to do with the Alumni
Memorial- Hall. and it is in short a
plan to make the hall more truly
memorial of certain great alumni.
The ekpense involved is so Ismail as
to be negligible, and a simple resolution of the Bdard of Governors
or whatever it is will suffice in a
parliamentary way.
Your correspondent therefore not
too respectfully suggests that the
several entries, which are now designated by the opening letters of
our Roman alphabet, should henceforth and forever be designed by
the names of distinguished alumni.
• • •
Your correspondent suggests that
each of the several important departments of this university be
given an entry to name for its favorite. By important, your correspondent means the chemical, the
physical, the biological, the medical,
and the new legal departments.
The sixth entry has already been
taken over by the alumni, who have
had it named after the late Judge
S.- S. Symington. The engineering
department is not, it is submitted,
entitled to an entry.

Pipe Smoker
Has a "Kick"
All His Own
St. Paul, Minn.
June 1, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
About five years ago, after trying
out many different styles of pipes
from the Missouri meerschaum to the
genuine meerschaum, including the
upside-down style made popular by
Vice-President Dawes, and experimenting with just about all the to-.
baccos then on the market except
Edgeworth,I finally decided that pipesmoking was not for me.
For the last year or so I noticed the
boys around the office here using
Edgeworth to the exclusion of all
other tobaccos and evidently getting
real pleasure from their pipes.
In April of this year I was in Canada
on a business trip and decided to take
another whirl at pipe-smoking. So I
invested a good share of my savings
in a pipe and a few cents additional
for a can of Edgeworth.
From then on I have been figuratively kicking myself around the block
about once each day when I think of
the five lean years I put in trying to
get along without a pipe. However, I
am trying to make up for lost time
and am succeeding quite well. Why
I failed to try Edgeworth long ago will
have to go down in history as an
unsolved question. But now that I
have found it, the years ahead look
rosy to me.
Very truly yours,
Ben Bayer

Underwriters' Agent Gives
Engineering Lecture

Speaking on a subject little known
but vastly important to the average person, Mr. George B. Aluldaur,
General Agent of the Underwriters'
Laboratories of Chicago and New
York, described the testing of various machines and other commercial
aPpliances presented to his organization for inspection. The lecture
was held last Wednesday and was
the second of a series of three lectures that are being held this spring
on engineering practice.
'The Underwriters' Laboratories
is a non-profit-making organization
sponsored by various Insurance organizations throughout the country,
for the purpose of standardizing and
testing the quality of all types and
classes of commercial products. The
general offices are at 'Chicago in a
large _building occupying a full block
and protected by every knoWn fire
and burglar safety device known.
Several hundred men are employed
merely in testing the commercial
products submitted. A small laboratory in New York City takes
charge of the examination of all
electrical devices.
Slides Most Interesting

Of most interest were the illustrations and slides—presented along
with the descriptions by Mr. Muldaur, showing the terrific tests put
on such objects as safes. In determining whether the Laboratories
will put,this approval on a certain
safe it is put in a very hot furnace
and baked for several hotirs; It is
removed, raised to a height of thirty
feet, and permitted to fall to a bed
of rock. It is then put in the furnace and reheated for a time. Then
it is removed and opened. If the
papers originally put in the safe are
burned or even charred the safe is
rejected.
